DOC.brief_summary: Cisplatin is a major anti-neoplastic drug used for the treatment of solid tumors. Its chief dose limiting side effect is nephrotoxicity. Twenty percent of patients receiving high-dose cisplatin undergo severe renal dysfunction. Acetazolamide and N-acetylcysteine (NAC) ameliorated Cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in rats. No study to date evaluated the protective effect of acetazolamide or NAC against cisplatin nephrotoxicity in humans. Aim of the study was to evaluate the effect of acetazolamide or NAC against cisplatin nephrotoxicity in humans compared to mannitol and to each other. Patients and methods. A total 52 patients receiving standard hydration measures for cisplatin were randomized to three groups: 20 patients receiving mannitol, 15 patients receiving acetazolamide and 17 patients receiving NAC. Patients` kidney function was monitored using serum creatinine, creatinine clearance and blood urea nitrogen; kidney injury was assessed using RIFLE criteria. Patients` liver function tests and hematological parameters were also monitored.
DOC.brief_title: Evaluation of the Effect of Acetazolamide, Mannitol and N-acetylcysteine on Cisplatin-Induced Nephrotoxicity
DOC.criteria: 1. Cancer patients to receive cisplatin based chemotherapy protocol. 2. Adult patients from 18 to 65 years. 1. Existing renal impairment ( Creatinine clearance <30 ml/minute) 2. Severe hepatic impairment (Child Pugh score C). 3. Hypersensitivity to sulfonamides. 4. Patients with chronic noncongestive angle closure glaucoma. 5. Hypersensitivity to sulphur compounds, Nacetylcysteine or any component of the formulation.
